text: I'm going to show you what gamma scalping is what the major components are and then walk you through an example so that you can see how this thing works from beginning to end what's up everybody Eric here and I'm stoked to talk a little bit about Gamma scalping because I actually think there's better opportunity now than there has been in the past few years so let's jump over and get right into what this is what is gamma scalping it's essentially Delta adjustments around a base trade so the way to think about it is you can scalp without having any sort of Base position and what I mean by that is you could try to benefit from the interim price movements of whatever it is that you're trading now the difference between that and Gamma scalping is we typically have some sort of Base trade on and we're adjusting the Deltas on that trade so when we're looking at these there's kind of two main categories there's long premium trades and then short premium trades now for gamma scalping more more often than not this is typically an Institutional practice so there's a lot of differences between what an institution will do with this and what retail seeks to do with it a lot of that has to do with transaction costs and things of that nature but that being said the normal way retail Traders will gamma scalp is typically having some sort of long

text: two lines the white line and the yellow line the yellow line is a 325 days to expiration option and then the white line is 31 really what I want you to note is the steepness in Delta that's what I'm highlighting because the closer we get to expiration the more Delta is going to move because options are approximating to one of two conditions either it's going to zero if it's out of the money or if it's going to one if it's in the money and this becomes steeper and steeper the closer we get to expiration okay now we need to talk about Gamma because it's called gamma scalping gamma is simply the rate of change of Delta so when we're thinking about Gamma scalping what we're doing is identifying how much our Deltas are going to move and then we're using that movement to buy in and out of the underlying so that we can cover our Theta costs so again right now Pretend We're long that straddle and as we start to get some movements we're going to trade the underline which I'll show you when we get into the example let's talk about some of the traits of gamma we have a 10 DTE gamma here in yellow and then a 30 DTE gamma here in white again notice how steep gamma becomes as we get closer to expiration the other thing that you're going to note is as we get closer to expiration

text: associated with that even though we don't have those upfront commissions on each order we send we're still paying for those trades via payment for order flow which comes in at we where we're seeing quotes and where we're getting filled at so don't allow the absence in the US at least of underlying commissions to mislead you into thinking that there's no cost associated with hedging there's still most certainly is so that's why I typically will hedge daily um maybe a little more frequently depending on the size of the position and how much Theta I'm losing so I'm just using a beginning of day entry and an end of day adjustment just so that you can see how this thing works okay so now let's fast forward time and instead of it being zero eight zero one am now it is 1601 this is Eastern Time and here's the trade that we have on our long straddle is now losing some money it's net p l or it's unreal SP L is negative 356. and the short Shares are showing a very small profit of plus 65 dollars so I'm gonna fast forward time over here as well just so that you could see exactly what this looks like and as that loads we can talk about it coming back over here this in my opinion for me would be a slightly premature Delta adjustment and this goes back to the preference in terms of what we're
